column2: CHAPTER XXXII.
column3: CHAPTER thirty two.

column2: PAWKINS'S IN JERMYN STREET.
column3: PAWKINS'S IN JERMYN STREET.

column2: The show of fat beasts in London took place this year on the twentieth day of December, and I have always understood that a certain bullock exhibited by Lord De Guest was declared by the metropolitan butchers to have realized all the possible excellences of breeding, feeding, and condition.
column3: The show of fat beasts in London took place this year on the twentieth day of December, and I have always understood that a certain bullock exhibited by Lord De Guest was declared by the metropolitan butchers to have realized all the possible excellences of breeding, feeding, and condition.

column2: No doubt the butchers of the next half-century will have learned much better, and the Guestwick beast, could it be embalmed and then produced, would excite only ridicule at the agricultural ignorance of the present age; but Lord De Guest took the praise that was offered to him, and found himself in a seventh heaven of delight.
column3: No doubt the butchers of the next half century will have learned much better, and the Guestwick beast, could it be embalmed and then produced, would excite only ridicule at the agricultural ignorance of the present age; but Lord De Guest took the praise that was offered to him, and found himself in a seventh heaven of delight.

column2: He was never so happy as when surrounded by butchers, graziers, and salesmen who were able to appreciate the work of his life, and who regarded him as a model nobleman.

column2: Pawkins's house was thoroughly old-fashioned in all things, and the Pawkins of that day himself stood behind the earl's elbow when the dinner began, and himself removed the cover from the soup tureen. column2: It might be a very fine thing to be asked to dinner with an earl, and John Eames had perhaps received at his office some little accession of dignity from the circumstance, of which he had been not unpleasantly aware; but, as he sat at the table, on which there were four or five apples and a plate of dried nuts, looking at the earl, as he endeavoured to keep his eyes open, and at the colonel, to whom it seemed absolutely a matter of indifference whether his companions were asleep or awake, he confessed to himself that the price he was paying was almost too dear.

column3: I don't see that at all.

column2: I haven't a shilling in the world.
column3: I haven't a shilling in the world.

column2: Girls don't care much for that.
column3: Girls don't care much for that.

column2: And then a clerk in the Income-tax Office!	And then a clerk in the Income tax Office!

column2: It's such a poor thing."
column3: It's such a poor thing."

column2: The other fellow was only a clerk in another office.
column3: The other fellow was only a clerk in another office.

column2: The earl living down at Guestwick did not understand that the Income-tax Office in the city, and the General Committee Office at Whitehall, were as far apart as Dives and Lazarus, and separated by as impassable a gulf.
column3: The earl living down at Guestwick did not understand that the Income tax Office in the city, and the General Committee Office at Whitehall, were as far apart as Dives and Lazarus, and separated by as impassable a gulf.

column2: Oh, yes, said Johnny; "but his office is another kind of thing, and then he was a swell himself."
column3: Oh, yes, said Johnny; "but his office is another kind of thing, and then he was a swell himself."

column2: By George, I don't see it, said the earl.
column3: By George, I don't see it, said the earl.

column2: I don't wonder a bit at her accepting a fellow like that.	I don't wonder a bit at her accepting a fellow like that.
column3: true

column2: I hated him the first moment I saw him; but that's no reason she should hate him.
column3: I hated him the first moment I saw him; but that's no reason she should hate him.

column2: He had that sort of manner, you know.
column3: He had that sort of manner, you know.

column2: He was a swell, and girls like that kind of thing.
column3: He was a swell, and girls like that kind of thing.

column2: I never felt angry with her, but I could have eaten him." As he spoke he looked as though he would have made some such attempt had Crosbie been present.
column3: I never felt angry with her, but I could have eaten him." As he spoke he looked as though he would have made some such attempt had Crosbie been present.

column2: Did you ever ask her to have you? said the earl.
column3: Did you ever ask her to have you? said the earl.

column2: No; how could I ask her, when I hadn't bread to give her?
column3: No; how could I ask her, when I hadn't bread to give her?

column2: And you never told her--that you were in love with her, I mean, and all that kind of thing.
column3: And you never told her-that you were in love with her, I mean, and all that kind of thing.

column2: She knows it now, said Johnny; "I went to say good-by to her the other day,--when I thought she was going to be married.
column3: She knows it now, said Johnny; "I went to say good by to her the other day,--when I thought she was going to be married.

column2: I could not help telling her then."
column3: I could not help telling her then."

column2: But it seems to me, my dear fellow, that you ought to be very much obliged to Crosbie;--that is to say, if you've a mind to--
column3: But it seems to me, my dear fellow, that you ought to be very much obliged to Crosbie;--that is to say, if you've a mind to-

column2: I know what you mean, my lord.	I know what you mean, my lord.
column3: true

column2: I am not a bit obliged to him.
column3: I am not a bit obliged to him.

column2: It's my belief that all this will about kill her.
column3: It's my belief that all this will about kill her.

column2: As to myself, if I thought she'd ever have me--"
column3: As to myself, if I thought she'd ever have me-"

column2: Then he was again silent, and the earl could see that the tears were in his eyes.
column3: Then he was again silent, and the earl could see that the tears were in his eyes.

column2: I think I begin to understand it, said the earl, "and I'll give you a bit of advice.
column3: I think I begin to understand it, said the earl, "and I'll give you a bit of advice.

column2: You come down and spend your Christmas with me at Guestwick."
column3: You come down and spend your Christmas with me at Guestwick."

column2: Oh, my lord!
column3: Oh, my lord!

column2: Never mind my-lording me, but do as I tell you.	Never mind my lording me, but do as I tell you.
column3: true

column2: Lady Julia sent you a message, though I forgot all about it till now.
column3: Lady Julia sent you a message, though I forgot all about it till now.

column2: She wants to thank you herself for what you did in the field."
column3: She wants to thank you herself for what you did in the field."

column2: That's all nonsense, my lord.
column3: That's all nonsense, my lord.

column2: Very well; you can tell her so.	Very well; you can tell her so.
column3: false

column2: You may take my word for this, too,--my sister hates Crosbie quite as much as you do.
column3: You may take my word for this, too,--my sister hates Crosbie quite as much as you do.

column2: I think she'd 'pitch into him,' as you call it, herself, if she knew how.
column3: I think she'd 'pitch into him,' as you call it, herself, if she knew how.

column2: You come down to Guestwick for the Christmas, and then go over to Allington and tell them all plainly what you mean."
column3: You come down to Guestwick for the Christmas, and then go over to Allington and tell them all plainly what you mean."

column2: I couldn't say a word to her now.
column3: I couldn't say a word to her now.

column2: Say it to the squire, then.	Say it to the squire, then.
column3: true

column2: Go to him, and tell him what you mean,--holding your head up like a man.
column3: Go to him, and tell him what you mean,--holding your head up like a man.

column2: Don't talk to me about swells.
column3: Don't talk to me about swells.

column2: The man who means honestly is the best swell I know.
column3: The man who means honestly is the best swell I know.

column2: He's the only swell I recognize.
column3: He's the only swell I recognize.

column2: Go to old Dale, and say you come from me,--from Guestwick Manor.
column3: Go to old Dale, and say you come from me,--from Guestwick Manor.

column2: Tell him that if he'll put a little stick under the pot to make it boil, I'll put a bigger one.
column3: Tell him that if he'll put a little stick under the pot to make it boil, I'll put a bigger one.

column2: He'll understand what that means."
column3: He'll understand what that means."

column2: Oh, no, my lord.
column3: Oh, no, my lord.

column2: But I say, oh, yes; and the earl, who was now standing on the rug before the fire, dug his hands deep down into his trousers' pockets. "I'm very fond of that girl, and would do much for her.
column3: But I say, oh, yes; and the earl, who was now standing on the rug before the fire, dug his hands deep down into his trousers' pockets. "I'm very fond of that girl, and would do much for her.

column2: You ask Lady Julia if I didn't say so to her before I ever knew of your casting a sheep's-eye that way.
column3: You ask Lady Julia if I didn't say so to her before I ever knew of your casting a sheep's eye that way.

column2: And I've a sneaking kindness for you too, Master Johnny.
column3: And I've a sneaking kindness for you too, Master Johnny.

column2: Lord bless you, I knew your father as well as I ever knew any man; and to tell the truth, I believe I helped to ruin him. He held land of me, you know, and there can't be any doubt that he did ruin himself.
column3: Lord bless you, I knew your father as well as I ever knew any man; and to tell the truth, I believe I helped to ruin him. He held land of me, you know, and there can't be any doubt that he did ruin himself.

column2: He knew no more about a beast when he'd done, than--than--than that waiter.
column3: He knew no more about a beast when he'd done, than-than-than that waiter.

column2: If he'd gone on to this day he wouldn't have been any wiser."
column3: If he'd gone on to this day he wouldn't have been any wiser."

column2: Johnny sat silent, with his eyes full of tears.
column3: Johnny sat silent, with his eyes full of tears.

column2: What was he to say to his friend?
column3: What was he to say to his friend?

column2: You come down with me, continued the earl, "and you'll find we'll make it all straight.
column3: You come down with me, continued the earl, "and you'll find we'll make it all straight.

column2: I daresay you're right about not speaking to the girl just at present.
column3: I daresay you're right about not speaking to the girl just at present.

column2: But tell everything to the uncle, and then to the mother.
column3: But tell everything to the uncle, and then to the mother.

column2: And, above all things, never think that you're not good enough yourself.
column3: And, above all things, never think that you're not good enough yourself.

column2: A man should never think that.
column3: A man should never think that.

column2: My belief is that in life people will take you very much at your own reckoning.
column3: My belief is that in life people will take you very much at your own reckoning.

column2: If you are made of dirt, like that fellow Crosbie, you'll be found out at last, no doubt.
column3: If you are made of dirt, like that fellow Crosbie, you'll be found out at last, no doubt.

column2: But then I don't think you are made of dirt."
column3: But then I don't think you are made of dirt."

column2: I hope not.
column3: I hope not.

column2: And so do I. You can come down, I suppose, with me the day after to-morrow?
column3: And so do i You can come down, I suppose, with me the day after to morrow?

column2: I'm afraid not.	I'm afraid not.
column3: true

column2: I have had all my leave."
column3: I have had all my leave."

column2: Shall I write to old Buffle, and ask it as a favour?
column3: Shall I write to old Buffle, and ask it as a favour?

column2: No, said Johnny; "I shouldn't like that.
column3: No, said Johnny; "I shouldn't like that.

column2: But I'll see to-morrow, and then I'll let you know.
column3: But I'll see to morrow, and then I'll let you know.

column2: I can go down by the mail train on Saturday, at any rate."
column3: I can go down by the mail train on Saturday, at any rate."

column2: That won't be comfortable.	That won't be comfortable.

column2: See and come with me if you can.
column3: See and come with me if you can.

column2: Now, good-night, my dear fellow, and remember this,--when I say a thing I mean it.
column3: Now, good night, my dear fellow, and remember this,--when I say a thing I mean it.

column2: I think I may boast that I never yet went back from my word."
column3: I think I may boast that I never yet went back from my word."

column2: The earl as he spoke gave his left hand to his guest, and looking somewhat grandly up over the young man's head, he tapped his own breast thrice with his right hand.
column3: The earl as he spoke gave his left hand to his guest, and looking somewhat grandly up over the young man's head, he tapped his own breast thrice with his right hand.

column2: As he went through the little scene, John Eames felt that he was every inch an earl.
column3: As he went through the little scene, john Eames felt that he was every inch an earl.

column2: I don't know what to say to you, my lord.
column3: I don't know what to say to you, my lord.

column2: Say nothing,--not a word more to me.	Say nothing,--not a word more to me.
column3: true

column2: But say to yourself that faint heart never won fair lady.
column3: But say to yourself that faint heart never won fair lady.

column2: Good-night, my dear boy, good-night.
column3: Good night, my dear boy, good night.

column2: I dine out to-morrow, but you can call and let me know at about six."
column3: I dine out to morrow, but you can call and let me know at about six."

column2: Eames then left the room without another word, and walked out into the cold air of Jermyn Street.
column3: Eames then left the room without another word, and walked out into the cold air of Jermyn Street.

column2: The moon was clear and bright, and the pavement in the shining light seemed to be as clean as a lady's hand.
column3: The moon was clear and bright, and the pavement in the shining light seemed to be as clean as a lady's hand.

column2: All the world was altered to him since he had entered Pawkins's Hotel.
column3: All the world was altered to him since he had entered Pawkins's Hotel.

column2: Was it then possible that Lily Dale might even yet become his wife?
column3: Was it then possible that Lily Dale might even yet become his wife?

column2: Could it be true that he, even now, was in a position to go boldly to the Squire of Allington, and tell him what were his views with reference to Lily?
column3: Could it be true that he, even now, was in a position to go boldly to the Squire of Allington, and tell him what were his views with reference to Lily?

column2: And how far would he be justified in taking the earl at his word?
column3: And how far would he be justified in taking the earl at his word?

column2: Some incredible amount of wealth would be required before he could marry Lily Dale.
column3: Some incredible amount of wealth would be required before he could marry Lily Dale.

column2: Two or three hundred pounds a year at the very least!
column3: Two or three hundred pounds a year at the very least!

column2: The earl could not mean him to understand that any such sum as that would be made up with such an object! Nevertheless he resolved as he walked home to Burton Crescent that he would go down to Guestwick, and that he would obey the earl's behest. As regarded Lily herself he felt that nothing could be said to her for many a long day as yet.

column2: Oh, John, how late you are! said Amelia, slipping out from the back parlour as he let himself in with his latch-key.
column3: Oh, john, how late you are! said Amelia, slipping out from the back parlour as he let himself in with his latch key.

column2: Yes, I am;--very late, said John, taking his candle, and passing her by on the stairs without another word.
column3: Yes, I am;--very late, said john, taking his candle, and passing her by on the stairs without another word.

column2: CHAPTER XXXIII.

column2: THE TIME WILL COME.

column2: Did you hear that young Eames is staying at Guestwick Manor?

column2: As these were the first words which the squire spoke to Mrs. Dale as they walked together up to the Great House, after church, on Christmas Day, it was clear enough that the tidings of Johnny's visit, when told to him, had made some impression.
